questions.text: A female patient with a BMI of 35 kg/m2 presents to you with a skin lesion in the Axilla as shown below. Which of the following condition is she most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic Syndrome

 

Option B:

 

  • Acanthosis Nigricans is the Illness depicted in the image. This patient is most likely to be suffering from Metabolic Syndrome based on the diagnosis.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans is characterized by thickened, Gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the Neck, Axillae, Inframammary creases, Waist, and Groin.
  • Insulin Resistance is the most accepted Hypothesis used to explain the Pathophysiology of the condition. The release of Epidermal Growth Factors in the Affected Area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Drugs such as Nicotinic Acid used to treat Hyperlipidaemia
  • Sudden onset of multiple Seborrhoeic Keratoses.

 

Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnoea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hypothyroidism

 

  • It is associated with Dry Coarse Skin, Weight Gain & Alopecia.

 

Option C: Addison’s disease

 

  • It is associated with hyperpigmentation of skin (but without velvety texture) which is prone to sun exposure & friction.

 

Option D: Hyperparathyroidism

 

  • It affects Kidneys & Skeletal system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with metabolic syndrome are at increased risk of developing skin conditions like acanthosis nigricans, which can manifest as hyperpigmented, velvety skin changes, often observed in the axilla.
  • Recognizing such skin changes can be important for identifying underlying metabolic issues.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 147, Page Nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynaecology 3rd Edition Page No 391

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with History of Bilateral Hilar Lymphadenopathy & Apple Jelly Nodules on Diascopy, presents with Skin Lesions as shown in the Pic. Identify this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lupus Pernio

 

Option B:

 

Lupus Pernio:

 

  • It is the nasal form of sarcoidosis.
  • It is more common in women.
  • Presents as red-brown or red violaceous nodules or plaques, generally multiple. It is usually asymptomatic.
  • Large bluish-red and dusky violaceous infiltrated nodules and plaques occur symmetrically on the nose,cheeks, ears, fingers, hands and toes.
  • The lesions may feel soft, doughy, or indurated.
  • Discrete nodules with a typical appearance (Apple Jelly nodules) on diascopy may be found at the edge sometimes.
  • It affects the nasal septum causing obstruction.
  • They invariably have multisystem disease.

 

Lofgren syndrome: Triad of

 

  1. Erythema nodosum
  2. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal adenopathies, with or without pulmonary infiltrates
  3. Acute Polyarthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lupus Pernio is a distinct cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by Violaceous, Indurated Plaques, Nodules, or Papules, typically affecting the Nose, Cheeks, Lips, and Ears.
  • Recognizing these skin lesions is important for the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 98, Page Nos 98.6-98.9

questions.text: A 60-Year-Old Male Patient presents with a sudden increase in the lesions given in picture. What should be suspected in this Pt?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Visceral Malignancy

 

Option B:

 

  • Seborrheic Keratosis is very common in elderly individuals which presents with Hyperpigmented lesions over body.
  • Clinical features: Common epidermal tumours called seborrheic keratoses are made up of a benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes. These lesions usually appear as well-defined, round, or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a characteristic stuck-on appearance.
  • Named sign in Seborrheic Keratosis: The Leser-Trelat sign, also known as the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses in association with skin tags and acanthosis nigricans, has been linked to a number of malignancies, including gastrointestinal (1/3rd, mostly adenocarcinomas) and lung cancers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Malignant Melanoma:

 

  • Malignant melanoma typically presents as a pigmented lesion with signs of asymmetry, irregular borders, color variation, and a diameter larger than 6 mm.
  • The sudden increase in the lesions is not a characteristic feature of melanoma.

 

Option C. Varicella:

 

  • Varicella (chickenpox) presents with vesicular skin lesions and is unlikely to cause a sudden increase in seborrheic keratosis-like lesions.

 

Option D. Nevi:

 

  • Nevi (moles) are benign skin lesions and do not typically cause a sudden increase in lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Leser-Trélat sign is characterized by a sudden increase in seborrheic keratosis lesions, which may be associated with an underlying visceral malignancy.
  • It is important to recognize this sign as it can be an early indicator of an occult malignancy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 133, 147 Page Nos 133.1 & 147.16

choices.text: Binkley's Spots is another name for Diabetic Dermopathy
Pinch Purpura can be seen in primary Systemic Amyloidosis.
Xanthelasma Palpebrarum are seen associated with Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia
Pretibial Myxoedema is seen in Hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements regarding skin manifestations associated with various systemic diseases EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Xanthelasma Palpebrarum are seen associated with Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia

 

Option C:

 

  • Xanthelasma Palpebrarum are seen in:
    • Familial hypercholesterolemia
    • Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (broad beta disease)
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis (chronic cholestasis)
  • They are not seen in type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial chylomicronaemia).
  • Clinical features: Upper eyelids and the region around the medial canthus (periorbital areas) are the sites most frequently affected by XP. They range in colour from pale yellow to yellow-orange and are relatively soft to the touch.

 

Xanthelasma Palpebrarum:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Binkley's Spots / Diabetic Shin Spots / Diabetic Dermopathy.

 

 

  • Clinical Presentation: Asymptomatic, oval, dull-red papules which evolve slowly on the shins, forearms, thighs, and over bony prominences, producing a superficial scale and atrophic brown scars.

 

Option B: Pinch purpura is diagnostic of Primary Systemic Amyloidosis.

 

 

  • Due to Fragility from amyloid deposition around cutaneous vessels, purpuric macules and ecchymoses, particularly in the periorbital area, develop with minor trauma.

 

Option D: Pretibial Myxoedema is seen in hyperthyroidism.

 

  • Pretibial Myxoedema: Presentation: Non pitting edema Anterior aspect of legs due to depositio of Glycosaminoglycans (GAGS).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skin manifestations associated with systemic diseases is important for clinicians as these signs can often provide valuable diagnostic clues to underlying medical conditions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 58, Chapter 62, Chapter 147, Chapter 149, Page No 149.14 149.20, Page Nos 58.10-58.11, Page No 147.19, Page No 62.3

questions.text: All of the following are correct matches of the diseases & the nutrient deficiencies associated with them EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acrodermatitis Enteropathica - Copper Deficiency

 

Option D:

 

  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica is associated with Zinc Deficiency (NOT Copper)
  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica is an Autosomal Recessive (AR) Disease and it is due to Zinc deficiency.
  • Gene related to Acrodermatitis Enteropathica is SLC39A4.
  • Associated with Triad of:
  1. Dermatitis of Periorificial and Acral Sites.
  2. Diarrhea
  3. Alopecia

 

Acrodermatitis Enteropathica

 

 

Treatment:

 

  • Zinc supplementation rapidly improves the condition within 24 to 48 hours. Lifelong supplementation needed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Phrynoderma:

 

  • Phrynoderma (Toad Skin) is common in Children.
  • Phrynoderma is associated with Multiple Nutritional Deficiencies including B Complex, Riboflavin, Vitamin C, Vitamin E, Essential Fatty Acids, and Malnutrition.
  •  Phrynoderma is also associated with Vit-A deficiency.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It manifests as groups of papules, each one around 3-4 mm in diameter, with a central keratotic plug.
    • The follicular distribution of the papules gives the skin a rough texture.
    • Although the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected, the elbows and knees are the most frequently affected body parts.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Diet correction and administration of multivitamin preparations.

 

Option B: Scurvy Cutaneous Manifestations:

 

  • Phrynoderma
  • Corkscrew Hairs - fractured and coiled hairs due to impaired keratin cross-links by disulfide bonds
  • Perifollicular hemorrhage and purpura
  • Bleeding Gums

 

 

Option C: Kwashiorkor:

 

  • Clinical features:
  1. ‘Flaky Paint' or 'Crazy Paving' Dermatosis
  2. Peripheral edema is a consistent feature due to the associated hypoproteinaemia.
  3. Hepatomegaly → Abdominal distention.
  • Flaky paint' or 'crazy paving' Dermatosis

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a genetic disorder characterized by impaired zinc absorption.
  • Understanding the correct associations between diseases and nutrient deficiencies is essential for diagnosing and managing nutritional disorders in clinical practice.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 63 Chapter 87 Page Nos 63.21-63.26 Page Nos 87.13-87.14

questions.text: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with Poor Wound Healing, Dermatitis, Diarrhoea and Alopecia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zinc

 

Option D: Zinc.

 

  • Zinc deficiency is indeed associated with the mentioned symptoms:
  • Poor wound healing: Zinc plays a crucial role in the synthesis of collagen and the maintenance of skin integrity. In its absence, wound healing processes are impaired.
  • Dermatitis: Zinc deficiency can result in skin problems, including dermatitis, due to its importance in skin health and immune function.
  • Diarrhea: Zinc deficiency can lead to gastrointestinal issues, including diarrhea. Zinc supplementation is often used to treat diarrhea in children in developing countries.
  • Alopecia: Hair follicles require zinc for normal growth and maintenance. A lack of zinc can lead to hair loss, known as alopecia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron:

 

  • Iron deficiency is associated with anaemia, fatigue, and pallor but is not typically linked to dermatitis, Diarrhea, or alopecia.

 

Option B. Calcium:

 

  • Calcium deficiency can lead to issues like muscle cramps, weak bones, and dental problems, but it is not primarily associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhea, or alopecia.

 

Option C. Magnesium:

 

  • Magnesium deficiency can cause muscle cramps, irregular heartbeat, and weakness, but it is not the primary mineral associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhea, or alopecia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zinc deficiency is associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia.
  • It is essential for skin health, immune function, and overall well-being, making it a critical mineral for various physiological processes.

 

Ref:  Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 81.17

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 806

questions.text: Which of the following mineral deficiency can lead to the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc

 

Option A.

 

Acrodermatitis Enteropathica (ADE)

 

  • It is characterized by Zinc Deficiency, which presents with symptoms such as Periorificial and Acral Dermatitis, Alopecia, and Diarrhea. The images show the typical dermatitis associated with zinc deficiency.

 

 

 

Post Zinc Supplementation of a Child with ADE.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Iron Deficiency:

 

  • While iron deficiency can cause skin changes, they are not typically as severe as those seen in the image. Iron deficiency may lead to pallor and in severe cases can cause glossitis or angular cheilitis, but not the widespread lesions seen in the images.

 

Option C. Calcium Deficiency:

 

  • Deficiency of calcium might lead to tetany or convulsions, dermatitis is not a characteristic feature.

 

Option D. Vitamin A Deficiency:

 

  • This typically leads to Xerosis (Dry Skin), Bitot's Spots, and Night Blindness, not the rash seen in the images.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica is caused by zinc deficiency and is characterized by Periorificial and Acral Dermatitis, Alopecia, and Diarrhea.
  • It is important to differentiate it from other deficiencies based on clinical presentation.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 81.17

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 806

questions.text: A child with a history of night blindness presented to you with the following findings over the knees. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

 

Option A:

 

  • Phrynoderma is a skin condition often associated with Vitamin A deficiency, which can also cause Night Blindness.
  • The condition is characterized by Hyperkeratotic, Follicular Papules, and the image provided suggests such a presentation.
  • Phrynoderma is not specific to vitamin A deficiency, and has been described in association with deficiencies in BComplex Vitamins, Vitamin C, Vitamin E and Essential Fatty Acids

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Keratosis Pilaris

 

  • This typically presents as small, rough bumps found on the upper arms, thighs, or cheeks.

 

 

  • They are not usually associated with systemic symptoms like night blindness.

 

Option C. Darier's Disease

 

  • This is a genetic disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques, primarily in seborrheic areas, not typically associated with night blindness.

 

Option D. Follicular Eczema

 

  • This manifests as itchy, inflamed skin around the hair follicles and is not associated with night blindness.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of phrynoderma, which is associated with vitamin A deficiency and presents with follicular hyperkeratotic papules, in a patient with a history of night blindness.Top of Form

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 63.7

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 797

choices.text: The Arthritis typically Mirrors Rheumatoid Arthritis.
The most implicated Causative Organism is E. Coli.
There is an association with HLA-Cw6.
The patient may also exhibit Conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with painful, erythematous, and vesicular lesions on the soles of his feet. He reports experiencing left ankle and knee joint pain, along with discomfort during urination. Examination reveals no evidence of rheumatoid nodules or symmetrical joint involvement. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding his likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The patient may also exhibit Conjunctivitis.

 

Option D:

 

  • Reiter's Disease:
    • The case presents with hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and soles suggestive of Keratoderma Blenorrhagica, is typically associated with Reactive Arthritis.
    • Reiter's Disease, also known as Reactive Arthritis, is characterized by the triad of Arthritis, Urethritis, and Conjunctivitis, often after a Genitourinary or Gastrointestinal infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The arthritis seen in Reiter's Disease, or Reactive Arthritis, is typically Asymmetrical and Oligoarticular, unlike the symmetrical Polyarticular involvement seen in Rheumatoid Arthritis.

 

 

Option B. The most commonly implicated organisms are Chlamydia trachomatis for sexually acquired cases and Campylobacter, Salmonella, Shigella, and Yersinia for enteric cases, not E. coli.

 

Option C. HLA-Cw6 is more strongly associated with psoriasis. Reiter's disease has a known association with HLA-B27.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The signs and symptoms of Reiter's disease, which include the classic triad of Arthritis, Urethritis, and Conjunctivitis, and understand its association with infections and HLA-B27, not HLA-Cw6.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 154.2

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 148

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who is a known case of diabetes, presents with lesion as shown in the picture below. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic Dermopathy

 

Option A. Dermopathy:

 

  • Diabetic Dermopathy is a skin condition commonly seen in individuals with diabetes, particularly those with longstanding or poorly controlled diabetes.
  • It is characterized by the presence of multiple brown macules and patches on the skin, usually found on the lower extremities, especially the shins.
  • These lesions are often round or oval and may vary in size.
  • Diabetic dermopathy can serve as a clinical marker for diabetes-related complications such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Granuloma Annulare:

 

  • Granuloma annulare is a different skin condition characterized by raised, reddish or skin-colored bumps arranged in a ring or arc shape.
  • It is not typically associated with diabetes.

 

Option C. Necrobiosis Lipoidica:

 

  • Necrobiosis lipoidica is another skin condition that appears as reddish-brown patches with a shiny, atrophic surface.
  • It is more commonly associated with diabetes but typically presents differently than the lesions in the picture.

 

Option D. Pretibial Myxoedema:

 

  • Pretibial myxoedema is a skin condition associated with hyperthyroidism, not diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diabetic Dermopathy is a common skin finding in individuals with diabetes, characterized by multiple brown macules and patches, often with atrophy.
  • Recognizing diabetic dermopathy can serve as a clinical marker for diabetes-related complications such as Retinopathy, Nephropathy, and Neuropathy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 64.2

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with asymmetric arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis two weeks following a diarrheal illness. He reports recent unprotected sexual encounters and has no significant past medical history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reactive arthritis 

 

Option B.

 

  • It is characterized by the triad of asymmetric oligoarthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis, typically occurring after either a genitourinary infection (often Chlamydia trachomatis) or gastrointestinal infection.

  • This patient's presentation is classic for reactive arthritis, often referred to as Reiter's syndrome.

 

Explanation:

Option A) Gonococcal arthritis

• This can cause arthritis and urethritis, but conjunctivitis is not typically a feature, and it usually presents more acutely with purulent arthritis.

Option C) Rheumatoid arthritis

•It is a chronic autoimmune disorder that typically presents with symmetric arthritis affecting the small joints of the hands and feet.

•It does not typically follow an infection and is associated with other systemic symptoms and signs.

Option D) Osteoarthritis

• It is a degenerative joint disease that is characterized by joint pain, stiffness, and loss of function, primarily affecting weight-bearing joints.

• It does not present with urethritis or conjunctivitis, nor it is related to an infectious process.

 

Educational Objective:

• Reactive arthritis has a classic triad of asymmetric arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis, typically following a genitourinary or gastrointestinal infection.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 154.2

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 148

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with history of Bilateral Hilar Lymphadenopathy & Apple Jelly Nodules on Diascopy, presents with Skin Lesions as shown in the Picture. Which of the following investigations are recommended in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ACE Enzyme Levels

 

Option A:

 

  • This is a recommended investigation because Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) levels are often elevated in sarcoidosis due to the increased production by Epithelioid Cells of Granulomas.
  • However, it is not specific to sarcoidosis as it can be elevated in other conditions as well.
  • The patient's history of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and apple jelly nodules on diascopy, along with the skin lesions shown in the image, are highly suggestive of Sarcoidosis.
  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that commonly affects the lungs, lymph nodes, and skin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. CXR:

 

  • Chest X-ray is an important investigation to evaluate the extent of Pulmonary involvement in sarcoidosis.
  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, which is a hallmark of the disease is already mentioned in the MCQ, so next best option would be ACE levels.

 

Option C. Giemsa Stain:

 

  • Giemsa stain is not a routine diagnostic test for sarcoidosis.
  • Giemsa stain is more commonly used for the detection of parasites and certain bacteria.

 

Option D. Tuberculin Test:

 

  • The tuberculin test may be considered in cases where tuberculosis is a differential diagnosis.
  • Patients with sarcoidosis can have anergy, which is a lack of reaction to the tuberculin skin test.
  • However, it is not specific to sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In suspected cases of sarcoidosis, measuring ACE enzyme levels can be a valuable diagnostic tool due to their frequent elevation in this condition, aiding in the confirmation of the diagnosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 98.7

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of diarrhea, dermatitis and mental retardation. It was also found that he was a maize eater. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pellagra

 

Option C:

 

  • Vitamin B3 / Niacin deficiency, or pellagra, causes diarrhea, dermatitis over sun-exposed areas, dementia, and, if untreated, death.
  • Diets high in maize and jawar put people at risk for Pellagra. Pellagra can be brought on by excessive alcohol use, the carcinoid syndrome, or Hartnup disease.

 

 

  • Pellagroid dermatitis features depicted in above image

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor:

 

  • This is a form of severe protein malnutrition characterized by edema, an enlarged liver with fatty infiltrates, and dermatosis.
  • The skin may appear flaky, with areas of redness and depigmentation, often described as a "flaky paint" dermatosis.
  • This occurs because of the breakdown of the skin barrier and can lead to secondary bacterial infections.

 

Option B. Night Blindness:

 

  • Night blindness, or nyctalopia, is primarily caused by a deficiency of Vitamin A. This deficiency affects the eyes, leading to problems seeing in low light or darkness. The symptoms described in the question don't point towards a vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Beri Beri:

 

  • Beri Beri is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). There are two main forms: wet beriberi (affecting the cardiovascular system) and dry beriberi (affecting the nervous system). The symptoms can include weakness, pain, and mental confusion, but the classic triad seen in pellagra is not characteristic of beri beri.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pellagra by recognizing its classic triad of Diarrhea, Dermatitis, and Dementia, especially in the context of a diet predominantly consisting of Maize, which lacks adequate Niacin and Tryptophan.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 63 Page Number 63.4

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acanthosis Nigricans

 

Option D:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is the illness depicted in the image.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
  • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea &non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
  • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pityriasis Rotunda

 

  • Description: This is a rare skin condition characterized by large, round patches of dry, scaly skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Melasma

 

  • Description: Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches, mainly on the Face (Cheeks, Bridge of the Nose, Forehead, Chin, and above the Upper Lip). It's often called the "Mask of Pregnancy."

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis

 

  • Description: An inflammatory muscle disease, dermatomyositis presents with skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • The rash is often reddish or purple, seen on the eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, and sometimes the chest and back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a Velvety Darkening of the skin in Body Folds.
  • There's a notable link between Obesity, Acanthosis Nigricans, and Metabolic Syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of Insulin Resistance.
  • Recognizing Acanthosis Nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying Systemic issues that may require comprehensive Medical Evaluation.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 147, Page Nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology 3rd Edition Page No 391

choices.text: B1 (thiamine)
B6 (pyridoxine)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, with a background of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, long-term alcohol abuse, and homelessness, is hospitalized due to acute pneumonia. During a ward examination, you observe a brownish-red discoloration on his face, neck, forearms, and lower legs, accompanied by skin scaling and cracks. He reports difficulties with eating and drinking, ongoing vomiting, diarrhea, and appears somewhat disoriented. Which vitamin deficiency might be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. B3 (niacin)


Explanation
•    Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by the four Ds: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia, and potentially Death if untreated. 
•    The skin changes noted as brown-red discoloration with scaling and cracking, particularly when exposed to sunlight, are indicative of dermatitis. 
•    The gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting and diarrhea, along with neurological signs such as disorientation, point towards the systemic effects of niacin deficiency, encompassing both digestive and mental disturbances.


Other Options
Option A. B1 (thiamine): Deficiency leads to beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, primarily affecting the cardiovascular and nervous systems, respectively. It does not typically cause the dermatological or extensive gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this patient.


Option B. B2 (riboflavin): Deficiency of riboflavin can cause angular cheilitis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis, but these symptoms are distinct from the extensive skin discoloration and systemic symptoms described.


Option D. B6 (pyridoxine): Deficiency primarily presents with peripheral neuropathy, irritability, depression, and dermatitis, but unlike niacin deficiency, it does not typically result in the severe digestive and mental symptoms observed in this case.


Educational Objective:
•    The crucial fact to remember from this case is that niacin deficiency, or pellagra, presents with a characteristic combination of symptoms including dermatitis (skin discoloration and scaling), diarrhea, dementia (disorientation), and can be fatal if untreated. 


Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 63 Page Number 63.4

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic female presents with asymptomatic lesions as shown in the image below. On examination there was no scaling associated over the lesions. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granuloma Annulare

 

Option B:

 

  • The patient's presentation of Asymptomatic Lesions without Scaling is suggestive of Granuloma Annulare.
  • This is a Benign Skin Condition that often presents as Annular Erythematous Non Scaly Plaques over Dorsum of the Hand.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tuberculoid Leprosy –

 

  • Tuberculoid leprosy can present with skin lesions, but it typically involves Sensory Loss, Nerve Involvement, and a Positive Skin Smear for Acid-Fast Bacilli. This patient's presentation does not match those characteristics.

 

Option C: Lupus Vulgaris –

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis and presents with reddish-brown plaques with apple jelly nodules on diascopy. This patient does not have the characteristic nodules.

 

Option D: Tinea Corporis –

 

  • Tinea corporis, a fungal infection, often presents with scaling and a more distinct border. The absence of scaling in this case makes it less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical features of granuloma annulare, which include asymptomatic lesions forming ring-like patterns without scaling, to arrive at the correct diagnosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 97.3

questions.text: Match the following nutritional deficiencies in Column A with its clinical features in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Correct matches:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

1-c Vitamin A Deficiency - Phrynoderma, which is a condition characterized by Follicular Hyperkeratosis due to Deficiency of Vitamin A.

 

2-a Vitamin C Deficiency - Bleeding Gums, a hallmark feature of Scurvy, which is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin C. Vitamin C is essential for Collagen Synthesis, and its deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, leading to bleeding gums among other symptoms.

 

3-b Vitamin B12 Deficiency - Beefy Red Tongue, also known as Glossitis, which can occur in the context of Vitamin B12 Deficiency, often part of the clinical syndrome of Megaloblastic Anaemia.

 

4-d Zinc Deficiency - Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, a condition specifically associated with Zinc Deficiency, characterized by Dermatitis, Alopecia, and Diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical features associated with Specific Nutritional Deficiencies:

 

  • Vitamin A deficiency is associated with Phrynoderma, Vitamin C Deficiency with Bleeding Gums, Vitamin B12 Deficiency with Beefy Red Tongue, and Zinc deficiency with Acrodermatitis Enteropathica.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 63.7, 63.19, 63.21, 63.25

questions.text: A 6-Year-old child presented with palpable purpura over lower extremities and buttocks. There was associated Joint Pain and Abdominal Pain. What is the treatment option of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocorticoids

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment for HSP. They are used to alleviate symptoms and reduce inflammation, especially in cases with severe abdominal pain or kidney involvement.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The condition described in the case is Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), which is characterized by Palpable Purpura over the Lower Extremities and buttocks, Joint Pain, and Abdominal Pain.
  • Azathioprine (Option A), Methotrexate (Option C), and Cyclosporine (Option D) may be considered in refractory cases of HSP or when glucocorticoids are contraindicated, but they are not the first-line treatment options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) is the use of glucocorticoids, especially in cases with severe symptoms such as abdominal pain or kidney involvement.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 102.15
